title: Kurwar
text:
Kurwar is a village and <a href="community%20development%20block">community development block</a> headquarters in <a href="Sultanpur%2C%20Uttar%20Pradesh">Sultanpur</a> tehsil of <a href="Sultanpur%20district">Sultanpur district</a>, <a href="Uttar%20Pradesh">Uttar Pradesh</a>, <a href="India">India</a>. It is located by the <a href="Gomti%20River">Gomti River</a>, 14 km northwest of Sultanpur on the road to <a href="Isauli">Isauli</a> and <a href="Haliapur">Haliapur</a>. The southern part of the village is on fairly high ground, but the area north of the main road is low-lying and prone to flooding. Kurwar historically was the seat of the <a href="taluqdar">taluqdar</a>i estate of the Raja of Kurwar, who was the head of the <a href="Bachgoti">Bachgoti</a> Rajput clan.
As of 2011, Kurwar has a population of 10,826, in 1,785 households. It has 4 primary schools and a community health centre. Kurwar hosts a market twice per week, on Mondays and Fridays; it mostly deals in cloth, pottery and <a href="ox">bullocks</a>. It also hosts a large <a href="Dussehra">Dussehra</a> festival involving dramatic reenactments of scenes from the <a href="Ramayana">Ramayana</a>. Vendors bring items such as <a href="earthenware">earthenware</a> pottery, <a href="hosiery">hosiery</a>, hemp ropes, cloth, toys, and sweets to sell at the fair. Kurwar is also the seat of a <a href="nyaya%20panchayat">nyaya panchayat</a> which also includes 13 other villages.
History.
Kurwar was historically the seat of the Raja of Kurwar, who was head of the <a href="Bachgoti">Bachgoti</a> Rajput clan and who lived in a palace here. The palace was built by the Court of Wards, and Raja Partab Bahadur Singh also built a large "<a href="zanana">zanana</a>" house which was completed in 1902.
The Rajas of Kurwar claimed descent from one Prithipat Singh; the ninth raja, Niwaz Singh, had two sons named Lachhman Singh (who inherited Kurwar) and Man Singh (who received the taluqa of <a href="Bhiti">Bhiti</a>; Lachhman Singh's grandsons all died without issue, and Sukhdev Singh, a descendant of Man Singh, seized Kurwar, and his descendants would subsequently reign as rajas. At the turn of the 20th century, the Kurwar estate consisted of 64 villages and 9 <a href="patti%20%28land%29">pattis</a> in the parganas of Miranpur and Baraunsa, and the raja also held the <a href="Hathgaon">Hathgaon</a> estate of 37 villages and 15 pattis in <a href="Faizabad%20district">Faizabad district</a>.
At the turn of the 20th century, Kurwar was described as a large village with "a very flourishing upper primary school, one of the best in the district," as well as a female dispensary maintained by the Raja of Kurwar. It was not, however a trade centre. The population as of 1901 was 3,004 people, including 2,297 Hindus and 707 Muslims. The main caste groups were <a href="Brahmin">Brahmin</a>s, Thakurs, and <a href="Kayasth">Kayasth</a>s.
The <a href="1951%20Census%20of%20India">1951 census</a> recorded Kurwar as comprising 36 hamlets, with a total population of 3,640 people (1,808 male and 1,832 female), in 852 households and 780 physical houses. The area of the village was given as 1,722 <a href="acre">acre</a>s. The village was listed as belonging to the <a href="pargana">pargana</a> of Miranpur and the <a href="thana">thana</a> of Kotwali. The village had a district board-run primary school with 276 students in attendance as of 1 January 1951.
The <a href="1961%20Census%20of%20India">1961 census</a> recorded Kurwar as comprising 37 hamlets, with a total population of 4,112 people (2,047 male and 2,065 female), in 795 households and 760 physical houses.. The area of the village was given as 1,722 acres and it had a medical practitioner, maternity and child welfare centre, and government-run <a href="dispensary">dispensary</a> with 2 male and 2 female beds. Average attendance of the twice-weekly haat was about 1,500 people, while attendance of the Dussehra fair was about 2,000.
The <a href="1981%20Census%20of%20India">1981 census</a> recorded Kurwar as having a population of 5,876 people, in 1,031 households, and having an area of 696.89 <a href="hectare">hectare</a>s. The main staple foods were listed as wheat and rice.
The <a href="1991%20Census%20of%20India">1991 census</a> recorded Kurwar (as "Kudwar") as having a total population of 7,428 people (3,826 male and 3,602 female), in 1,181 households and 1,156 physical houses. The area of the village was listed as 996.89 hectares. Members of the 0-6 age group numbered 1,426, or 19% of the total; this group was 53% male (757) and 47% female (669). Members of <a href="scheduled%20caste">scheduled caste</a>s numbered 758, or 10% of the village's total population, while no members of <a href="scheduled%20tribes">scheduled tribes</a> were recorded. The <a href="literacy%20rate">literacy rate</a> of the village was 52% (2,152 men and 984 women, counting only people age 7 and up). 1,970 people were classified as main workers (1,736 men and 234 women), while 10 people were classified as marginal workers (all women); the remaining 5,448 residents were non-workers. The breakdown of main workers by employment category was as follows: 635 cultivators (i.e. people who owned or leased their own land); 530 agricultural labourers (i.e. people who worked someone else's land in return for payment); 0 workers in livestock, forestry, fishing, hunting, plantations, orchards, etc.; 0 in mining and quarrying; 188 household industry workers; 70 workers employed in other <a href="manufacturing">manufacturing</a>, processing, service, and repair roles; 4 <a href="construction%20worker">construction worker</a>s; 245 employed in trade and commerce; 23 employed in transport, storage, and communications; and 285 in other services.
